entry.title: A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025
entry.content:
A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 was more than an event ‚Äî it was a full day of learning, exchange of ideas, and meaningful community moments. Hosted with the support of AWS, Mindset, ROJO Integrations, and SAP Press, the gathering brought together professionals from across the SAP ecosystem: developers, consultants, architects, leaders, learners, and enthusiasts.

Right from the first interaction at the registration desk, there was a sense of purpose and curiosity in the air. Everyone walked in with a shared goal: to understand where the world of enterprise technology is heading next.

SAP GGN Community Core Team for SAP Insider Track GGN 2025 ‚Äì Third Edition

 

A Warm and Powerful Beginning

The day began with organized registrations and structured networking, giving participants the opportunity to connect and align their expectations for the event. The event kicked off with a warm welcome from Aseem Khera, Location Head, ‚ÄãSAP Labs India Gurugram‚Äã clearly outlining the agenda and highlighting the day‚Äôs objectives. His opening remarks established a clear framework and set the tone for subsequent sessions.

Aseem Khera, Location Head, ‚ÄãSAP Labs India Gurugram‚Äã 

 

This was followed by an inspiring video keynote from Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. In her address, she highlighted the importance of the SAP Community, the effects of artificial intelligence on the global economy, and SAP's AI-First, Suite-First strategy.

Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM

 

 

The morning session continued with an inspiring SAP Business AI strategy talk by Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture ‚ÄãPrivate Cloud Products titled ‚ÄúTransforming Business with SAP Business AI.‚Äù He provided a comprehensive and insightful overview of the ongoing transformation of SAP Business AI strategy.

Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture ‚ÄãPrivate Cloud Products

 

A huge shout-out to our amazing host, Akansha Tiwari! Your energy, charm, and effortless hosting truly made the event unforgettable. Your poised and engaging presence kept the momentum alive throughout the entire morning session. The way you connected with the audience, guided transitions with ease, and maintained a vibrant atmosphere played a pivotal role in the event‚Äôs overall success.

 

Akansha Tiwari - Host of the Event

 

 

Three Tracks, Three Journeys, One Purpose

The event went beyond treating technology as a concept, organizing learning into three parallel tracks tailored to different participant needs. Each track offered practical, actionable insights‚Äîcatering to leaders, developers, and hands-on learners alike‚Äîallowing attendees to explore strategies, tools, and real-world applications in a focused and meaningful way aligned with their roles and professional goals.

Agenda of the day with Session Title & Speaker Names

 

Track 01: SAP Business AI Strategy & Roadmap‚Äã / SAP Business AI Products

Ideal for architects, leaders, and decision-makers

This track focused on understanding how organizations can evolve their systems, processes, and governance models. Speakers shared their experiences on:

  • Strengthening enterprise value
  • Navigating regulatory landscapes
  • Modernizing GRC
  • Evolving SuccessFactors experiences
  • Positioning SAP‚Äôs latest offerings for business outcomes

The conversations weren‚Äôt theoretical‚Äîthey were grounded in real decisions and real impact.

 

Track 02: Embedded AI in SAP Solutions‚Äã / Building with SAP AI Agents‚Äã

Built for developers, engineers, and product builders

This track showcased what happens when ideas take shape. From building custom solutions to exploring new toolkits, participants learned how to translate concepts into working applications.

Sessions covered:

  • Building custom agents
  • Optimizing catalogs
  • Ensuring safety in high-risk industries
  • Handling real-time situations in S/4HANA
  • Enhancing HR processes with modern tools

Every session was centered around solving real business challenges.

 

Track 03: Hands-On Workshops

For those who understand best by doing

This track remained one of the most crowded for a reason‚Äîit was all action.

Participants practiced:

  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from an image‚Äã
  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from business requirements‚Äã
  • Generate and enhance an app‚Äã
  • Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP‚Äã

It was a genuine ‚Äúroll-up-your-sleeves‚Äù experience.

 

Afternoon Deep Dives: Practical Stories & Lessons

Post lunch, the sessions transitioned to in-depth case studies and practical, real-world scenarios. Speakers provided valuable insights on topics such as:

  • Detecting fraud within business systems
  • Optimizing development cycles
  • Managing responsible digital processes
  • Enhancing commercial operations
  • Improving employee experiences in live environments

These discussions effectively bridged technology with day-to-day organizational decisions, demonstrating tangible applications and measurable outcomes for participants.

 

The Heart of the Day: Conversations & Community

SAP Inside Track events have always been known for their community-driven spirit. Gurugram 2025 continued that legacy beautifully.

Corridors, break areas, and even the workshop tables stayed alive with:

  • Debates on implementation challenges
  • Exchange of tips and best practices
  • Discussions on new roles and skills
  • Shared excitement for the future of enterprise systems

For many, these conversations were just as valuable as the sessions themselves.

 

A Fitting Closure

The day wrapped up with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal networking. People walked out with new connections, refreshed perspectives, and a deeper appreciation for how powerful the SAP community is when it comes together.

entry.title: Re: Lumpsum issue - guidelines show 0 and Lumpsum field cannot be filled in the form
entry.content: I would need to see your guidelines to see why they are blank. You have to ensure your guideline parameters are met for each employee and the lump sum guideline field is visible. Also, make sure you have a default value at the bottom with * for each parameter so ensure if an employee falls through, those guidelines will appear. Remember, the guidelines are read in numerical order, meaning row 1 then row 2 etc. If they hit a match with row 1, the system will never hit row 2.

entry.title: Re: Alternate Reconciliation Account and¬†Overwriting control accounts initiated by MM through ERS
entry.content: Hi @KoijMikami, Currently, there is no standard way to use alternate reconciliation accounts with ERS in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. The MRM_ERS_DATA_Modify_CE BAdI does not include reconciliation account parameters, and forcing overwrite through Open FI is not feasible due to the automated nature of ERS processing. Consider process alternatives or submit enhancement requests for future product development.

entry.title: Main resource and additional resource cost journal ( 6***) not generated after Production Operation
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are implementing SAP Business ByDesign for a customer in the garment manufacturing industry and have scoped both Manufacturing and Product Costing functionalities.

Issue:
Our Bill of Operations consists of three operations, and each operation has a main resource (Labour) and an additional resource (Indirect Costs) assigned. However, upon completing the production operation, the system only posts the raw material consumption journal (Raw Material Inventory CR / Work in Process DR).
The system does not post any resource cost journals (6*** internal services CR / Work in Process DR).

Expectation:
For each completed operation, we expect ByDesign to post resource cost journals to WIP, so that month-end WIP correctly reflects both material costs and resource (labour and indirect) costs at the operation level.
In addition, for Actual Costing to work correctly, resource costs must be posted during the production confirmation process.

Request for Clarification:

  1. Is it standard functionality in ByDesign that resource costs (both main and additional resources) are posted to WIP when the production task associated with an operation is completed?

  2. What could be the possible reasons or configuration gaps that would prevent the system from posting resource cost journals?

Thank you,
Sagar

entry.title: Re: Error M8_2210 during MIRO. Item is not consistent
entry.content: consider the following steps: 1. Check Service Entry Sheet: Ensure that the Service Entry Sheet related to the purchase order is correctly created and approved. Any discrepancies in the Service Entry Sheet can lead to inconsistencies during MIRO processing. 2. Review Purchase Order Details: Verify that all details in the purchase order, especially those related to asset categories, are correctly maintained. Inconsistencies in asset categorization can trigger this error. 3. Account Assignment: Ensure that the account assignment in the purchase order is complete and correct. Missing or incorrect account assignments can cause the system to flag the item as inconsistent. 4. Configuration Check: Review the configuration settings for invoice verification in the system. Ensure that all necessary settings for handling asset-related purchase orders are correctly configured. 5. System Trace and Logs: Run a system trace or check logs to identify any specific inconsistencies or errors that might not be immediately visible. This can help pinpoint the exact cause of the inconsistency. If these steps do not resolve the issue, consider reaching out to SAP support for further assistance, providing them with detailed logs and screenshots to facilitate troubleshooting.

entry.title: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Errors during the Mass Creation of Business Partner Relationships
entry.content:
Hello Experts,
we have the following issue during the migration of 2000 Business Partner relationships.
We are using the app  "Manage Mass Creation Processes - BP Relationships (F6560A)" to import BP-Relationships for existing Business Partners.
We split the import into batches of 500, but if we try to activate these, then the system activates 100 of those and then gives the following error:
"User SAP_WFRT is processing the business partners relationship XY"
The error counter varies, if you reprocess the activation, sometimes it goes up one or two, then it drops down, till it activates another 100 entries. Eventually it activates all 500, so we were able to import the first batch. All of this takes a lot of time.

Our question is, is this standard behavior ? Can the tool only import 100 relationships at once and then needs time to process some stuff in the background ? 

We appreciate and advice on how to improve this process.
Best regards
Lukas

entry.title: Prompt-Driven Development: Building Full-Stack SAP CAP Apps from User Stories
entry.content:
Introduction

  • What if you could translate a business requirement into a functional, full-stack application with a single prompt?
  • How much faster could you deliver value if the foundational code and project scaffolding were generated for you in seconds?

This is the new reality powered by SAP Build Code and its integrated AI copilot, Joule.

As a turn-key environment on the SAP Business Technology Platform, it unifies the entire development lifecycle, from coding to deployment.

This post demonstrates how to build a full-stack SAP CAP application directly from a user story, showcasing how

generative AI is fundamentally reshaping the developer experience.

 

Business Requirement

Build an SAP CAP application based on the requirements in the user story below:

User Story

As a contract administrator, I want to create and manage contracts and ‚Äòparties involved‚Äô information in the system,

so that I can effectively track and handle legal agreements and ‚Äòparties involved‚Äô interactions.

Contracts can cover a vast range of agreements, such as sales contracts, service agreements and employment contracts.

Party involved: A ‚Äòparty involved‚Äô is an individual, organization, or entity that purchases goods, products, or services from another party,

typically a business or seller.

Common attributes of a contract might include:

  1. Contract ID: A unique identifier for the contract.
  2. Party involved Identification Number: A unique identification number for the party involved.
  3. Contract Type: The type of contract (e.g. sales, service, employment).
  4. Start Date: The date on which the contract becomes valid.
  5. End Date: The date on which the contract expires (if applicable).
  6. Status: The current status of the contract (draft, active, expired, terminated, etc.)

A typical ‚Äòparty involved‚Äô has the following attributes:

  1. Party involved Identification Number
  2. Party involved Name: It refers to the given name of a person or entity, or a label by which they are addressed or identified.
  3. Party involved Address: It refers to a physical location where an individual, business, or entity is situated or can be reached.
  4. Party involved Contact Information

Acceptance Criteria

Scenario 1: List All Contracts

Given I am logged into the contract management system, when I launch the SAP Fiori application to maintain contracts,

then I should be able to view the list of all the contracts in a list without pressing the GO button.

The list of all the contracts should have : Contract ID, Party involved Identification Number, Contract Type and Start Date. 

The list of filters should include Contract Type, Contract Status and Start Date.

Scenario 2: View Contract Details 

Given I am logged into the contract management system, when I select a specific contract from the list of SAP Fiori application,

then I should be able to view the contract details and parties involved information.

 

Joule's Generative AI-based SAP CAP App Development

Prerequisites

  • Get a Free Account on SAP BTP Trial
  • Setup SAP Build Code

1. Create a New Project using SAP Build Lobby

Create a Project

 

Click the Application Tile

Full-Stack

Full-Stack Node.JS

Contract Management

Contract Management

Project Created

2. Build a Full-Stack CAP Application via Prompt

Click the created project to open it in SAP Business Application Studio

Open Joule From the Activity Bar and  select the ‚Äô/cap-gen-app` slash command

Generate a CAP Application

Prompt the user story description(refer to Business Requirement section above) to Joule and click send.

Joule tackles complex tasks by breaking them into steps, each with a suggested prompt.

Diffrerent Steps

To simplify the process and provide full context, replace the content of each step with the complete user story prompt.

Then, save and run to generate each step's artifacts.

Accept the Code.

Accept the Code

Generated Artifacts

3. Add UI to the Application

Create a new Fiori elements Application.

Fiori Elements Application

 

3. Preview the Application

Click run to preview the Application.

Run the Application

The application‚Äôs preview is displayed.

Application Preview

Launch the contract management app.

Contract Management

Select a contract from the list to view its details.

Select Contract

 

Contract details

Conclusion

The journey from user story to a functional, full-stack application‚Äîonce a multi-day endeavor‚Äîis now accomplished in minutes.

With SAP Build Code and its AI copilot, Joule, this dramatic acceleration signals a fundamental paradigm shift.

The developer's role is being elevated from the meticulous craft of writing code to the strategic art of guiding its creation.

Joule operates as the quintessential collaborator, executing the foundational groundwork to liberate developers to focus

on high-value business logic and innovation.

SAP Build Code is therefore more than a tool; it's the dawn of an era where the speed of technology finally

matches the ambition of business.

 

Further Information

SAP Build Code

#SAPBuildCode #Joule #SAPBTP

 

______________________________________________________________________________________________

 

 

Best Regards,
Anuradha Dhingan

entry.title: Re: Why does SAP always use Periodic Unit Price for valua...
entry.content:
Dear @esterwang,

Question 1.

  • In SAP, price control has exactly two options:
    • S Standard price
    • V Moving average price / periodic unit price

More details from SAP Press blog:

https://blog.sap-press.com/accounting-views-in-the-material-master

  • With V, SAP explicitly defines that the valuation of stock is based on the moving average / periodic unit price, not the standard price. In SAP help under Valuation with Moving Average Price, SAP states that with moving average price control, a new material price is calculated after every goods movement or invoice receipt

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/bef1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/bbd9b6ce0be14516ad7868da0982024a.html

  • Because Material Ledger is mandatory in S/4HANA for material valuation, the moving price for price control V is technically the Periodic Unit Price (PUP) in the ML tables. The official Material valuation in S/4HANA content explicitly points out that Material Ledger is required and refers to simplification item/SAP Note 2267835 about statistical moving average price

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2267835

So when you choose price control V, you are telling the system: Value this material based on the moving average / periodic unit price (PUP), not based on a fixed standard price. That‚Äôs why you always see PUP as the valuation basis.

Concrete technical evidence:

  1. Field semantics in MBEW
    The table documentation for MBEW shows:
    • Price control values: S = Standard price, V = Moving average price/periodic unit price
      The valuation is then done with:
    • STPRS Standard price only used when price control = S
    • VERPR Moving average price / PUP used when price control = V
  2. Material Ledger / Accounting 1 view
    The classic Actual Costing documentation explains that in Accounting 1, the periodic unit price for the previous period is displayed as the moving price when price control = V
  3. In the SAP PRESS book Material Ledger in SAP S/4HANA, the reading sample shows a material with price control V and two price fields Standard Price and Per unit price. The note explicitly states that because price control is V, Per unit price is the valuation price and Standard price is not

Summary: You observe that valuation always using the periodic unit price is exactly what SAP designed

Question 2.

  • SAP defines in configuration Define Price Control for Material Types (OMW1) that you can choose V moving average price/periodic unit price or S standard price as the valuation method for a material type. But this customizing just sets defaults it does not change how valuation is calculated
  • The help for Price Control and Material Price Determination clarifies that:
    • Price control = V valuation is at moving average/periodic unit price
    • Price control = S valuation is at standard price

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/5af1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

  • The system logic that decides which field (STPRS vs. VERPR) is used in FI postings is not configurable it is standard program logic based on price control

What configuration does influence

  • Material price determination (2 vs 3) tells ML how to calculate PUP and variances, not which field to use for valuation.
    • With Price Determination 2 (transaction-based) and price control V the material is valued at moving average price with price control S, at standard price
    • With Price Determination 3 (single-/multilevel) and price control S, Actual Costing determines a PUP and can revalue inventory but the preliminary valuation during the period is at standard price

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/6cf1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/6cf1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

Question 3.

In S/4HANA, when price control = V, the Standard Price field is basically statistical / reference only, it‚Äôs not used for stock valuation.

Practically, under V, standard price is used for:

  1. Planning and costing
    • As a reference price in cost estimates (CK11N/CK40N) or CO planning.
    • For comparisons between target (standard) and actual (PUP/MAP).
  2. Information and reporting
    • To store a management/planned cost for the material, independent of the moving/PUP valuation.
  3. Conversion scenarios
    • During conversions or switching between S and V, SAP sometimes copies one price into the other to avoid valuation jumps, but once a period is running with V, STPRS is no longer the controlling price

Summary: From a pure valuation perspective, standard price has no posting effect when price control is V.

Question 4.

Below SAP Help documentation for version On-Premise and Cloud:

  1. Price Control and moving average price
    • Valuation with Moving Average Price clearly states that with moving average price control, a new material price is calculated after every goods movement / invoice / settlement

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/bbd9b6ce0be14516ad7868da0982024a.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/bef1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

    • Negative Stocks at Moving Average Price ‚Äì explicitly refers to Price control V Moving average price/periodic unit price in Accounting 1

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/96bf9ad642cf4b26a29595e3d573fb8c/3657b953cccbb34ce10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/04c8a518f5934c1faf690f30f4b74722.html

  1. Basic concepts of price control and ML
    • Basic Concepts of Price Control describes Moving average price (Periodic Unit Price) and ML indicator shows that for MAP/PUP valuation, price control V is used

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/erpscm/3362168424.html

  1. Price Control and Material Price Determination
    • Help topic Price Control and Material Price Determination explains how price control and price determination interact and that Actual Costing for PUP requires price control S with price determination 3, reinforcing that V is the MAP/PUP path, S is standard-price path

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/af9ef57f504840d2b81be8667206d485/5af1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

  1. Transaction-based price determination
    • Articles on Material Price Determination in SAP Material Ledger and Materials 2V price determination 2 price control V show the standard combination 2V and that these materials are valued at moving average price

More details below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/material-price-determination-in-sap-material-ledger-sap-s-4hana-public/ba-p/13556561

SAP Notes below:

  • 2267834 S4TWL Material Ledger Obligatory for Material Valuation
    Confirms that Material Ledger is mandatory in S/4HANA hence PUP is central to valuation
  • 2267835 S4TWL Material Valuation Statistical moving average price
    Explains how the former statistical moving average price concept changes in S/4HANA and how the MAP/PUP field MBEW-VERPR behaves

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/ficontrolling/3361878146.html

These notes don‚Äôt change the basic rule, but they show SAP official stance on price fields and ML in S/4HANA

SAP Press

  1. Blog: Accounting Views in the Material Master adapted from Introducing the Material Master in SAP S/4HANA
    • Describes price control S vs V price control V is explicitly Moving Average Price/Periodic Unit Price, a variable price calculated based on goods movements and invoice postings

More details below:

https://blog.sap-press.com/accounting-views-in-the-material-master

  1. Blog: What Is the Difference Between Moving Average Price and Standard Price in SAP?
    • Illustrates that when price control field contains value V, the system uses the moving average price method: inventory is posted at the average price after each receipt when it‚Äôs S, the system always uses the fixed standard price and posts variances separately

More details below:

https://blog.sap-press.com/what-is-the-difference-between-moving-average-price-and-standard-price-in-sap

These are good external but still very official-feeling references

Question 5.

From SAP design perspective you are meant to choose one of two costing philosophies per material:

  1. Standard Costing (price control = S)
    • Valuation at a fixed standard price for the period.
    • All differences go to price difference accounts.
    • Actual Costing (PUP) with ML is an additional periodic view you can choose to revalue or not.
  2. Moving / Actual Costing (price control = V)
    • Valuation always follows the current average/periodic unit price derived from actual receipts and adjustments.
    • No separate ‚Äústandard price‚Äù basis for valuation.

Letting standard price drive valuation while price control = V would:

  • Contradict the meaning of price control in MM and FI
  • Break a lot of ML and reconciliation logic
  • Make postings and cost flows ambiguous which price is real for stock vs. variances

That‚Äôs why SAP keeps a clear split:

  • If you want valuation at standard price, use price control S ideally with price determination 3 for Actual Costing
  • If you want valuation at actual average/periodic cost use price control V

Summary: For price control = V in S/4HANA, the valuation price is always the moving average / periodic unit price field (MBEW-VERPR). The Standard Price field (MBEW-STPRS) is then only informational. This is standard SAP design and not something you can switch by configuration

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Lease in Accounting - migration / special flow
entry.content:
Hello @marcel_f 

Thank you for your question.

First, let me address the reason why you see the ‚Äúspecial flow‚Äù. In Lease Accounting the system always reconciles lease liability and right of use (ROU) asset. If, at your chosen valuation date, those two balances are not equal, the system will place the valuation cash flow as a special flow. It will then post it to the account you assigned in your valuation rule. This could easily happen during migration especially when you:

  • Fix an interest rate and the valuation date in your new contract, but
  • You forget to model all past changes (e.g., rent charges or index changes) that happened in your legacy system.

That means your system therefore calculates a present value of 341,195,38 EUR while the migrated ROU asset is 329,544,76 EUR . Then the system books the gap of 11,650,62 EUR as negative equity change (special flow IB00) in other to ensure ROU and liability balances are aligned. You can find more details on that here: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3055448

Second, the response you received on why you cannot fix both NPV and interest rate is correct. You cannot have both a manually fixed NPV and fixed rate at the same time. If you try to force both, you will break the internal logic and your subsequent calculation will not longer match IFRS 16 formulas. This is exactly what you experienced.

Finally, the public cloud does not offer any customising, SSCUI or BAdI that can suppress IB00. You can only functionally avoid it by modelling your historic lease condition so that the present value equals the ROU amount. Otherwise, I recommend you:

  • Treat IB00 as the technical adjustment that aligns your migrated ROU and liability.
  • Make sure your special flow accounts in your valuation rule are set to appropriate equity and ROU adjustment accounts.
  • Also, ensure you document in your accounting manual that this item represents the difference between the legacy balances and the balance implied by the new valuation.

For more guidance on Leasing configuration, see the link below:

https://help.sap.com/doc/76d00f8803a845a28297e5ca3087cfd4/7.0.2/en-US/SAP%20Leasing%20-%20Configuration%20Guide%202011.pdf

entry.title: How to Modify Standard SLED using a BAdI- VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT
entry.content:
Synopsis- There should some functionality either to influence( change) the Shelf Life Expiry Date( SLED) or Remaining shelf life in some exceptional cases, primarily in Consumer based industry.

Requirement- Recently working with Food Processing company, we were tasked to reduce SLED by some N days after standard calculation. The business involves Finished goods produced as 'Fresh' but its latter converted into new Product Called as 'Fresh as Frozen'. In this process of product conversion, Mat 2 Mat transfer(Fresh to Fresh as Frozen), a new SLED is also calculated for target material on the day of posting. Primarily, SLED of new product has to be reduced by 2 Days.

Solution- Since the core of the solution was built on custom RF( Using /SCWM/POST and some Idea from MIGO( WM Packing) New screen), we called a BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT. Basically the BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT is meant to change the process parameters in the shelf life expiration handling. The SLED of a material is changed during the goods movement posting process( Mvt Type) called inside the BAdI.

Badi has the method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS allows to change all the relevant parameters of shelf life expiration date processing for goods movements.

Requirement- Recently working with Food Processing company, we were tasked to reduce SLED by some N days after standard calculation. The business involves Finished goods produced as 'Fresh' but its latter converted into new Product Called as 'Fresh as Frozen'. In this process of product conversion, Mat 2 Mat transfer(Fresh to Fresh as Frozen), a new SLED is also calculated for target material on the day of posting. Primarily, SLED of new product has to be reduced by 2 Days.

Solution- Since the core of the solution was built on custom RF( Using /SCWM/POST and some Idea from MIGO( WM Packing) New screen), we called a BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT. Basically the BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT is meant to change the process parameters in the shelf life expiration handling. The SLED of a material is changed during the goods movement posting process( Mvt Type) called inside the BAdI.

Badi has the method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS allows to change all the relevant parameters of shelf life expiration date processing for goods movements.

Using this, the SLED parameters of the material master can be changed.

  • Total shelf life (C_MHDHB)

  • Remaining shelf life (C_MHDRZ)

  • Period indicator (C_IPRKZ_HBD/C_IPRKZ_RLZ)

  • Rounding rule (C_RDMHD)

The two additional parameters C_HSDAT and C_VFDAT allow changes to the contents of dialog fields Date of manufacture (DM07M-HSDAT_INPUT) and Shelf life expiration date (DM07M-VFDAT_INPUT).In below example, BAdI was called in custom RF( Which also had Batch Creation Bapi along with Mat 2 Mat conversion logic with HU creation)

Once Material 2 Material transfer is triggered, batch was created with reduced SLED( Minus 2 days from Standard calculation)

Date of Production= 04.12.2025

Total Shelf Life=16 days

Stnd SLED= 04.12.2025+ 16= 20.12.2025

Revised SLED by BAdI= 20.12.2025- 2= 18.12.2025( The offset days is maintained TVARV at Material group level)

All changes are recorded in Batch master.

CALC and CCHECK can be changed as required in method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS (for example 'Check only' => C_CALC = SPACE, C_CHECK = 'X'). We used Plant +Mvt Type to stop the recalculation of SLED by passing C_CALC=SPACE as other plants should not be impacted with this change.

Please read all the documentation of BAdI mentioned in documentation carefully before implementing it.

The Preliminary What‚Äôs New is available only for a short period ahead of a release. The What‚Äôs New then becomes available on the release date. 

On the release date, you can easily find What‚Äôs New topics for SAP ICS using the What‚Äôs New Viewer by applying just a few filters:

entry.title: The Future of Procurement and Maintenance: Bridging the Gap for Lasting Impact
entry.content:
The Future of Procurement and Maintenance: Bridging the Gap for Lasting Impact üöÄ

In today‚Äôs rapidly evolving business landscape, the intersection of procurement and maintenance is more critical than ever. The recent conversation with Aaron Horne, SAP Solution Advisor and a newly appointed member of the SAP Center of Excellence, sheds light on the challenges, opportunities, and emerging trends shaping the future of procurement, especially in maintenance, repair, and operations (MRO). This post distills the most salient insights from the discussion, offering actionable takeaways for professionals navigating this dynamic space.

From Engineering to Procurement: A Unique Perspective üîÑ

Aaron‚Äôs journey from mechanical engineering and oil refinery project management to procurement advisory highlights the value of cross-functional expertise. His transition was driven by firsthand experience with the migration from Oracle to SAP, where he saw the importance of connecting maintenance data and processes with procurement systems. This blend of technical and operational knowledge enables a deeper understanding of the real-world needs of maintenance teams‚Äîa perspective often overlooked in traditional procurement strategies.

The Maintenance‚ÄìProcurement Divide: Breaking Down Barriers üõ†Ô∏èü§ù

A recurring theme in the discussion is the historical friction between maintenance professionals and procurement teams. Maintenance managers, focused on keeping plants running, often perceive procurement as a barrier‚Äîmore concerned with cost savings and compliance than operational continuity. Aaron candidly admits to having ‚Äúhated‚Äù procurement processes in his previous roles, not because of the people, but due to conflicting priorities. The key insight here is the need for empathy and collaboration: procurement must understand the urgency and complexity of maintenance operations, while maintenance teams should appreciate the value procurement brings in supplier management and compliance.

Technology as an Enabler: AI, Automation, and User Experience ü§ñ‚ú®

Emerging technologies, especially AI and automation, are transforming the procurement‚Äìmaintenance relationship. The transcript highlights several forward-looking use cases:

  • Generative AI for Diagnostics and Inventory: Imagine a technician describing equipment symptoms and AI instantly identifying the right parts from inventory, streamlining repairs and reducing downtime. This not only improves efficiency but also enhances user experience for maintenance professionals.üß†
  • Predictive Analytics for Supply Chain: AI-driven forecasting can anticipate changes in maintenance schedules, ensuring suppliers are prepared for sudden spikes in demand. This proactive approach minimizes disruptions and supports better planning.üìä
  • Document Intelligence: AI tools that can sift through hundreds of pages of manuals to extract relevant procedures or warranty information empower technicians to act quickly and accurately.üìö

These innovations promise to make procurement tools more appealing and accessible to end users, fostering greater adoption and maturity in enterprise systems.

Collaboration and Continuous Improvement: The Path Forward ü§≤üîÑ

The future of procurement and MRO lies in ongoing collaboration and feedback. Aaron emphasizes the importance of involving maintenance professionals in procurement decisions‚Äîfrom supplier selection to process design. Organizations that bring ‚Äúboots on the ground‚Äù into the conversation are better positioned to align priorities and avoid costly missteps. Moreover, continuous improvement‚Äîadopting new features, refining processes, and maintaining open channels for product feedback‚Äîensures that both procurement and maintenance can adapt to changing business needs.  

Conclusion: Building Bridges for Sustainable Success üåâ

The conversation with Aaron underscores a powerful message: the future of procurement is not just about better products or smarter technology, but about building bridges between teams, fostering empathy, and driving continuous improvement. By embracing collaboration, leveraging AI, and prioritizing user experience, organizations can unlock new levels of efficiency and resilience in their supply chains.

Ready to shape the future? Share your thoughts, feedback, or experiences in the comments below‚Äîlet‚Äôs keep the conversation going! üí¨ email: thefutureofprocurement@sap.com

üåê OpenSAP: Entire Series HERE!

üçé Apple Podcasts: Listen on Apple!

Spotify:  Listen on Spotify HERE!

Audible: Listen on Audible HERE!

entry.content:
With immediate effect, the final What's New information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4 is now available.

To access the final What‚Äôs New information, please use the What‚Äôs New Viewer. In addition, the final Product Assistance (aka Application Help) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4 is available. Please use the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Help Portal page to access it.

For you as a customer, we recommend to also use the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool. The Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What‚Äôs New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4 will be available in RASD within the next few days. A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login. We recommend to use RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you as a customer.

You can use the commenting feature for What‚Äôs New. With this feature, authors can evaluate your feedback and incorporate it into the documentation, if needed. We hope that by opening this channel of communication, we can learn how to further improve our What‚Äôs New content for you. To use this feature, you need to be logged into the Help Portal. The feature will only be available in the English version of the documents. To learn more about how the feedback process works in SAP Help Portal, see Giving Documentation Feedback.

entry.title: Re: Manage Service Orders & Maintenance Order within SSAM...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

Initially, SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM) is a unified solution that allows you to manage both asset management and maintenance services, regardless of the business process (IS-U or any other). Therefore, there is no need to implement two separate mobile applications. You can use a single mobile application to manage both maintenance orders related to asset management and those associated with IS-U.

However, you should note that the design and configuration of the application may vary slightly depending on the specific requirements of each scenario. SAP SSAM offers flexibility in terms of configurations and functionalities that you can enable or disable based on the type of process you are managing, allowing you to have a single application for both types of processes. It will only be necessary to segment or differentiate the screens, functionalities, or roles according to the process you are managing (Asset Management or IS-U).

SAP Field Service Management (FSM) is designed to be as flexible as possible and allows you to configure and manage different scenarios within a single company instance or configuration. You do not need to create separate companies to manage different processes.

Instead of creating separate companies, FSM allows you to manage different operational units or entities within a single company configuration through service organizations and operational entities. This functionality will enable you to manage various maintenance and service processes within the same organizational structure without complicating the configuration with multiple instances.

However, if you have very specific needs or a high degree of complexity in the operation that justifies separating the configurations, you always have the option to implement additional configurations. But in most cases, managing everything from a single configuration is more efficient and cost-effective.

We have a similar solution, but what really helped us integrate everything was SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI). We had to develop an integration between SAP S/4HANA, SAP Field Service Management, and SAP Service Cloud, and it was through CPI that we were able to do so. Thanks to this integration, we only had to use the SAP FSM mobile app, without the need to implement any other additional applications.

entry.title: How can DM support creation of ESRS Report
entry.content:
In this blog, we'll explore how DM can simplify the creation of ESRS Report, ensuring
compliance while reducing manual effort. Navigating sustainability reporting can be
complex, but DM can be your ally. From SCT (Sustainability Center Tower) datalinking
to xbrl mapping, from taxonomy upload to creation of ixbrl instances, throughout this blog you'll discover practical insights and best practices to make your sustainability reporting efficient and reliable.

Let's turn complexity into clarity.

 

Step 1: Setting Up Reports in SAP DM

Start by creating four reports within the required reporting period:

- Annual Data Repository (Excel Report)
- Annual ESG Report (Word Report)
- iXBRL Instance (iXBRL Report)
- XBRL Taxonomy (Taxonomy Report)

Step 2: Configuring the Reports

1. Annual Data Repository (Excel Report)

Create the necessary chapters and subchapters in this report according to the ESG topics the Report needs to cover as in the example below:

Each subchapter can be linked to a specific topic, making it easier to organize and map data.


2. Annual ESG Report (Word Report)

Set up chapters that mirror a complete ESG Report, including Cover Page. Table of Contents, Introduction, and other necessary sections as in the example below:

These chapters can later be linked to data in the Excel Report, ensuring a consistent flow of information.


3. XBRL Taxonomy (Taxonomy Report)

Upload the ESRS taxonomy provided.

Go to the "Upload" tab and click "Choose File" to upload the Taxonomy.

Move to the "Taxonomy Entry Points" tab to import the taxonomy entry points, ensuring that they match your reporting requirements. Once the Entry Point is selected it can be imported by clicking in the "Import Entry Point" button as below:

In case you want to know if and how an XBRL scenario is supported by SAP Disclosure Management 10.1; or a new taxonomy version has been announced or released by your regulator and you want to check whether DM supports it - please check note 2138659 - DM XBRL Scenario Support - SAP for Me

3.1. Taxonomy entrypoints (iXBRL Report)


After uploading the taxonomy, you select an entrypoint when creating an XBRL instance or tagging your report. This because:
  • Taxonomies are large and contain many concepts.
  • Entrypoints filter the taxonomy to only include relevant concepts for your filing type.
  • This improves performance and ensures compliance with the regulator‚Äôs requirements.
Which entrypoint should be selected?

It depends on:

  • Regulatory requirement (e.g., ESMA ESEF for Europe, SEC for US).
  • Type of report (Consolidated vs. Individual financial statements).

Why does it matter?

Selecting the wrong entrypoint can:

  • Include unnecessary concepts.
  • Cause validation errors.
  • Make your report non-compliant with the regulator‚Äôs filing rules.

Official Sources for Taxonomies

IFRS (ESEF filings in Europe):

  • Download from ESMA‚Äôs official website:  European Securities and Markets Authority - ESEF Reporting Manual & Taxonomy.
  • ESMA publishes the ESEF taxonomy package (based on IFRS) every year.

US GAAP (SEC filings):

  • Download from SEC‚Äôs website: SEC.gov | Taxonomies and Schemas

Other jurisdictions:

  • Local regulators often provide their own taxonomy (e.g., UK FRC, German OAM).


4. iXBRL Instance (iXBRL Report)

The system automatically creates five essential chapters:

  • XBRL Units: Define units (e.g., EUR, kWh, MWh, percentage, tCO2e). See the example below:

  • XBRL Contexts: Set up contexts such as Baseline Year, Current Year, and Target Years. See the example below:

  • XBRL Taxonomy: Manage the taxonomy for tagging data.

  • XBRL Footnote: Add explanatory notes (optional, if required).

  • XBRL Typed Members: Configure typed members, used for advanced tagging
    and additional categorization.


Step 3: Building the Excel Data Repository

Connect the Excel Report (or Briefing Book) to SCT (Sustainability Control Tower) for data synchronization. This ensures that sustainability metrics and disclosures remain consistent across systems.

Note that the loaded column should appear with the green check mark for it to be connected.

Design tables, charts, and other elements as needed based on ESRS requirements, ensuring clarity and compliance.

Populate these elements with data sourced from the BDx sheets generated after the SCT connection ensuring all figures are accurate and up-to-date.

If Briefing Books are being used, leverage their dynamic features for narrative-driven reporting and automated updates, reducing manual effort and improving auditability.

 

Step 4: Tagging Data Using XBRL Mapper

Open the XBRL Mapper from SAP Disclosure Management tab in Excel. Please note that DM XBRL Mapper add-in is separate component complementary to DM Client.

Click on "Start" button for the SAP DM XBRL Mapper to Open Mapping Area.

Once it opens, load taxonomy that will show in the Mapping Area on the left side of the
Excel as below:

Tag each value in the report with the required properties:

  • Concept: The specific ESG metric or category.

  • Context (Period): The reporting period (Baseline, Current, Target).

  • Units: Measurement units (e.g., EUR, kWh).

  • Dimensions (optional): Further define values using categories (e.g., Countries)

Tagged values will appear in green, while incompletes tags will show in yellow as the two pictures below:

Note that in the second picture, since the Context is not selected, the value will show as yellow.

Use the search bar to quickly find relevant concepts:

There is also the option to select "Mapping Overview" which will give you an overview of
whatever is tagged in the file as shown below:


Step 5: Linking Excel Data in the Word ESG Report

Go to each chapter in the Word report.

Use DM‚Äôs functionality to pull data from the Excel report into Word, ensuring consistency.

Apply tagging in the Word document where needed, the same way you did for Excel values, but in this case particularly for text, sentences, or paragraphs matching ESG concepts.

 

Step 6: Configuration set up

Work on the Configuration for each chapter with required/needed details. After changing the configuration, click on "Save" to apply the changes.


Step 7: Finalizing the Reports

For the iXBRL instance, click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button at the top-level report to generate the XBRL file as shown below:

Review the Inline Viewer in iXBRL, where you can activate the XBRL Elements view (top right corner box) to verify tagged values and their properties.

For the Word ESG Report, click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù to produce the final document, just like it is done for any other Word Report.

Note that the result can only be opened from "Revision tab". Download the latest revision.

 

This Blog guides you through the main steps to ensure that your reports are accurate, compliant, and easy to maintain.

Useful materials:

2138659 - DM XBRL Scenario Support - SAP for Me

Disclosure Management - Checking the iXBRL mapping | SAP Help Portal

ESMA‚Äôs website:  European Securities and Markets Authority

SEC‚Äôs website:  SEC.gov | Taxonomies and Schemas

entry.title: ASUG Best Practices for Oil, Gas, and Energy Recap
entry.content:
In early October, we kicked off ASUG Best Practices for Oil, Gas, and Energy in Houston, an event full of great energy and valuable insights. This year, there was a special focus on the collaboration needed to navigate the industry‚Äôs future.

Watch the recap video here:

 

A few highlights stood out:

  • It was fantastic to see our strategic vision come to life in the keynote panel with SAP‚Äôs Head of Oil, Gas, and Energy Stephane Lauzon, Head of Product Management for Oil, Gas, and Energy Klaus Borkenstein, and Managing Partner Sumanth Gurumurthy. Having Kurt Aerts, Business Venture Executive from ExxonMobil join them to share how they are scaling their cloud transformation with RISE with SAP was a powerful example of co-innovation in action. Their story of modernizing for long-term agility is a testament to what partnership can achieve.
  • The conversations also moved beyond strategy and into practical application. We saw a huge interest in Business AI, not just as a concept but as a tool to solve real-world challenges. The workshop led by SAP's Kelly Boyer and Sumit Shah, and the panel with our partners at AWS, explored tangible use cases that can drive efficiency and innovation right now.
  • A vision is only as good as the plan to achieve it, and Stephan Klein‚Äôs keynote laid out a clear path forward by announcing the new SAP Model Company for Core Energy. This practical accelerator is designed to offer a more predictable modernization journey, helping customers maintain a clean core for continuous innovation and more easily blend AI into their core business processes.
  • But the most valuable sessions are always customer-led. The packed room for Chevron's session was a testament to this, where they detailed their transformation using SAP Business Technology Platform as a strategic enabler for their clean core. It was a fantastic example of true partnership, showing how they co-innovate with SAP to influence our roadmap and extend that innovation into the Industry Cloud.
  • This spirit of peer learning was just as evident in the data management panel with Aldo Leon from Messer, Laxman Challa from Southwest Gas, and Priya Kesavulu from Chevron as they shared real-world experiences and actionable strategies around SAP Business Technology Platform, SAP Master Data Governance, and enterprise data strategy. 

A big thank you to ASUG for hosting such a vital event, to all the customers and partners who shared their stories, and to the SAP team on the ground. The path forward for the energy industry is complex, but the collaborative spirit surrounding the event in Houston produces confidence in our shared success.

entry.title: SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence 2025
entry.content:
Good news! The learning journey Discovering Business Intelligence using SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence has been updated and now it includes the latest features of 2025.

The three courses will help you master the BI Launch Pad and Web Intelligence tools. 

The first course, titled Discovering SAP BusinessObjects BI Launch Pad, is suitable for business users, analysts, and consultants who want to begin with SAP BusinessObjects.

The course will enable you to:

  • Use Web Intelligence tools to display, interact with, and filter data. 
  • Configure your settings for an improved user experience. 
  • Schedule your documents efficiently and export them. 
  • Share an interactive Web Intelligence document with someone who does not have access to SAP BusinessObjects using the WIDX format. 

The next course, titled Exploring the Fundamental Concepts of SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence, is ideal for users who have completed the BI Launch Pad course and want to create their own documents.

The course will enable you to:

  • Retrieve only the relevant data for your analysis by applying filters at the query level. 
  • Design and format documents that effectively communicate complex analysis to decision-makers. 
  • Write basic formulas and variables‚ÄØto customize your analysis. 
  • Transform your static documents into interactive dashboards using the new interactive report filters. 

The third and final course, titled Exploring the Advanced Concepts of SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence, is designed for users who have completed Exploring the Fundamental Concepts of SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence and are ready to tackle more complex reporting challenges.

The course will enable you to:

  • Build queries based on a universe, a Microsoft Excel workbook, and a Web Intelligence document. 
  • Visualize and prepare data, then build cubes in Data mode. 
  • Define and apply input and output contexts to control calculation results. 
  • Write complex formulas and variables‚ÄØto customize your analysis. 

In this learning journey, you'll explore each course through easy-to-understand explanations, helpful visuals, and short videos.

If you want to practice, you have two scenarios to choose from:

  • Hands-on exercises with guided simulations, which are free.
  • Hands-on exercises with an exercise handbook and access to an SAP practice system. You need a subscription to the SAP Learning Hub portal.

Pass all the quizzes and receive a digital badge that will allow you to share your recently acquired knowledge across your social and professional networks.

Start your journey today and unlock the full potential of your business data with SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence!

entry.title: 02 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Clean Core Guidelines
entry.content:
The purpose of this blog is to share Clean Core guidelines for SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, based on my experience. This is not official SAP documentation or recommendation.

Clean Core is a key topic in SAP S/4HANA Transformation projects and must be adopted as part of the S/4HANA Journey. SAP has delivered tools, frameworks, and Strategy documents to support it, but I haven't seen much content for SAP SuccessFactors HCM projects. I hope this blog addresses this to some extent.

Why is a clean core essential in SAP SuccessFactors HCM?

 Clean Core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing an agile, innovative, and efficient SAP SuccessFactors HCM system, reducing technical debt and manual effort, and adopting a framework for building a maintainable system that leverages standard capabilities wherever possible.

If you are using SAP ERP HCM as Core HR, the system has evolved over the years and is usually customized to support your business processes, Integrations, and reporting. There is a valid reason for customization, but it introduced long-term challenges, technical debt, and high maintenance costs, which are well known, and every customer raises concerns about them.

SAP SuccessFactors HCM Clean Core Guiding Principles: 

  1. Business Processes: Standardize processes (fit-to-standard) to increase efficiency and adapt to market shifts.
  2. Data: Maintain high-quality, consistent data and implement robust governance to improve reporting, Integration, and analytics.
  3. Integration: Use standard APIs (OData, Web Services, ISC), Packaged Integrations, Event Driven Architecture (EDA), and direct API-based integrations to avoid complex custom integrations and Data gaps.
  4. Operations and Upgrades: Manage the lifecycle, ensure efficient monitoring, and adopt the new features of the SAP SuccessFactors HCM system.
  5. Extensibility: Built customer-specific, unique requirements using Extension Center Objects and SAP BTP CAP extensibility using the OData APIs to decouple customizations from the core for upgrade stability and build UI experience using Fiori and implement workflow /automation capabilities using SAP Build.

Business Process Clean Core governance framework:

This is a high-level framework that you could enhance based on your project structure and governance model.

Recommendations for Implementing Clean Core Guiding Principles:

 

  1. SAP SuccessFactors HCM Product Capabilities: Understanding the product capabilities is key to implementing or adopting fit-to-standard clean core guidelines. If the implementation resource lacks SME-level experience, the solution will likely be suboptimal and will usually require significant customization. 2
  2. Guiding principles and standards for each work stream: Create guiding principles and leading practices for each work stream (Functional, Data, Integration, and Extensibility), and ensure the project implementation team, including the customer and SI resources, must follow them as part of implementation to produce outstanding results. 
  3. Skills resources from SI: Having skilled resources from SI (Solution Architect, Functional Leads, and Technical Architect) who are familiar with the clean core implementation is key. Ensuring they own the quality of the work is key and should be part of the statement of work. 
  4. Preferred success service: Preferred success customers -leverage SAP's preferred success services like solution launch checks and success checks to review the SF configuration, Design, Integration strategy, and Integration code during the implementation. 
  5. Review Implementation Design Principles (IDPs): Based on my experience, IDPs are key assets for clean core guidelines. They provide structured guidance for addressing challenging customer requirements and frequently asked questions during the design and implementation phases of a project.

https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/implementation-design-principles#sap-successfactors-recruiting-management-and-employee-central-integration 

      6. SuccessFactors Architecture Leading Practice (ALP): ALP is another key asset for clear core guidelines, and it provides a set of recommended configuration decisions and guidance on topics associated with a SuccessFactors implementation, and a recommendation to drive positive outcomes aligned with the intended system design, leveraging proven success from previous deployments, and avoiding pitfalls.

 https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/architecture-leading-practices

 7. Integrations: Integration is a common area where extensive customization is done, which adds technical debt and high maintenance costs. Make sure that the resources who built integrations have.

 Prior experience in building integrations for SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

  • Understanding of SAP SuccessFactors APIs leading practices and Integration tools.
  • Strong integration design skills .
  • Understanding of packaged integrations and capabilities.
  • Integration Center and SAP Integration Suite Capabilities, and when to use these tools for custom integrations. 

 8. Leverage standard capabilities to capture quality data: Implementing proper validation business rules and framework to capture data is key . 

9) Data retention and Purge Data: Setting up the proper data retention rules and purging unnecessary data based on your data retention requirements will help you maintain key data. 

10) Monitoring Tools:  Leverage standard capabilities offered by SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite and SAP Solutions like Cloud ALM to monitor the jobs and schedules, which reduces system maintenance costs. 

11)Handling Product gaps: Some requirements will challenge the product capabilities, and they will be identified as gaps. Now, how you handle the product gaps is very key, based on my experience below,

  • Check if the functionality can be achieved using Extension Center Objects ( MDF). 
  • If MDF is not a solution, then check the Product roadmap to see if anything is planned in the upcoming releases. 
  • If Options 1 and 2 are not viable, then check if the partner has built any BTP Extension solutions in the App store. 
  • If a partner solution is not available, you can leverage the SAP BTP Extensibility Framework to extend SAP SuccessFactors and build the required functionality.

Commonly Asked Questions: 

 1)Creating custom fields and extension Center Objects is deviating from the clean core?

 No. But it is essential to check whether the functionality can be achieved using standard fields before using custom fields and the extension Center (MDF) object.

 2)How can I check if my SI is implementing and following clear core guidelines? 

Having the right skill resources for the project implementation is key. It is strongly recommended that key SI resources be validated before onboarding.

 3) What are the assets SAP has delivered for SI and Customers?

 I have used the following assets, and they have always helped.

  •  Implementation Design Principles covering all topics.
  • Architecture Leading Practices.
  • Process Maps.
  • Leading practices document.

  4)What are the areas that cause technical debt in SAP SuccessFactors HCM? 

Technical debt refers to the implied cost of future rework, Manual work, and maintenance resulting from choosing quick, short-term implementation or configuration solutions over more robust, long-term best practices. 

  • Integrations with External systems ‚Äì Building custom integrations with Poor Integration Design and coding standards
  • Manual workarounds and manual data maintenance processes
  • Customizations over Standard Functionality, Creating custom fields and MDF objects without governance.
  • Not ready to optimize business processes and build a solution that requires so much effort to maintain.
  • Not automating data imports.

5) Is optimizing business processes a must for a clean core?

 Yes. Optimizing some of the business processes is not possible due to various factors, which is reality, but as a customer having a mindset to optimize is very key, and checking the solution design options from the SI team and walking through with business and HR is always recommended.

entry.title: From Adrenaline to Assurance: How SAP Commerce Cloud Customers Made Peak Season Routine
entry.content:
Black Friday and Cyber Monday have long been the ultimate stress test for digital commerce. For many businesses, these high-traffic events once meant long nights, constant monitoring, and firefighting to keep systems running. For SAP Commerce Cloud customers, last year marked a turning point ‚Äì SAP-led proactive readiness strategies helped businesses stay ahead of risk and keep experiences smooth. This year, those strategies were not only repeated but enhanced by SAP, making peak season feel routine for leading brands even as order volumes surged.

Why SAP‚Äôs Proactive Approach Keeps Getting Better

When every second counts, prevention is better than cure. automation. SAP Commerce Cloud customers who embraced SAP‚Äôs proactive playbook last year doubled down this year with expanded coverage and smarter automation. SAP AI-driven insights continuously monitored capacity, configuration, and operations, so action happened before customers noticed.

Automated checks replaced manual lists, and support teams were ready to step in early ‚Äì quietly resolving issues before they became problems.

The result? A stronger, more unified, signal-led workflow that kept everything running seamlessly across consecutive peak seasons.

What Was Enhanced This Year ‚Äì and Why It Mattered

  • Earlier Start ‚Äì Preparations began weeks sooner, making readiness the default.
  • Broader Coverage ‚Äì More environments monitored; more signals tracked.
  • Smarter Insights ‚Äì AI models refined for sharper detection and faster recommendations.
  • Weekly Expert Reviews ‚Äì Turning meaningful signals into action before issues could escalate.

These SAP-driven enhancements meant less administrative effort, faster resolutions, and even greater confidence during the busiest shopping days of the year.

Behind the Scenes: How It Worked

  • Signal intelligence within SAP Commerce Cloud flagged performance, capacity, and configuration risks early.
  • AI-guided validations in SAP workflows turned insights into clear, actionable tasks.
  • Proactive SAP Support kicked in before thresholds became incidents.
  • Shared visibility aligned SAP operations and support for faster decisions.

Results at a Glance

  • Uninterrupted availability throughout the peak season
    Systems stayed online and stable during the busiest shopping days.
  • Faster analysis times ‚Äì improved by double digits
    Issue detection and resolution were significantly quicker compared to previous years.
  • Top-tier customer effort ratings for proactive support
    Customers rated the support experience highly because problems were prevented or resolved with minimal effort on their part.
  • Hundreds of potential issues resolved before impact
    Risks were identified and fixed early, avoiding disruptions for shoppers.
  • Major disruptions were prevented, ensuring smooth operations for nearly all customers
    Proactive measures kept severe-impact issues to near zero.

Who Benefited Most?

These benefits were felt across every SAP Commerce Cloud customer touchpoint ‚Äì from shoppers to business teams:

  • Shoppers Enjoyed Seamless Experiences
    Fast-loading pages, smooth checkout, and accurate inventory updates ‚Äì no frustrating delays.
  • Customers Felt Confident
    Reliable performance meant trust during big purchases, without fear of crashes or payment failures.
  • Support Was Faster and Quieter
    Issues were resolved behind the scenes before most customers even noticed.
  • Everyone Got What They Came For
    Deals stayed accessible, carts intact, and orders processed without hiccups ‚Äì maximizing satisfaction.

What‚Äôs Next

The journey doesn‚Äôt stop here. Businesses are extending this proactive approach year-round, scaling AI-driven detection, and broadening coverage to keep every season stress-free.

The goal? Continuous, intelligent readiness with SAP ‚Äì so you‚Äôre prepared well before the first order lands.

Keep your next peak season on track:

  • Talk to your SAP team about peak‚Äëseason preparedness for SAP Commerce Cloud
  • Join the SAP community conversation to share tips and get answers
  • Learn more about AI that‚Äôs woven into every SAP process

0:00 Intro

5:38 Micro-integrations in AEM
